Every broadcaster or network operator who receives a notice under subsection (2) shall, within two days after its receipt, consult with representatives of the registered party or eligible party that sent the notice for the purpose of reaching an agreement on the requests contained in it.

If no agreement is reached under subsection (3) within two days after the commencement of the consultation required by that subsection, the matter shall be referred to the Broadcasting Arbitrator who shall decide on the requests without delay and give notice of his or her decision to the broadcaster or network operator and to the representatives of the registered party or eligible party that made the requests.
In making a decision under subsection (4), the Broadcasting Arbitrator shall take into account the following principles:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that each registered party and each eligible party should have the freedom and flexibility to determine the proportion of commercial time and program time to be made available to it and the days on which and the hours during which that time as so proportioned should be made available; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that any broadcasting time to be made available to a registered party or eligible party should be made available fairly throughout prime time.

Subsection.Text: A decision of the Broadcasting Arbitrator under subsection (4) is final and binding on the registered party or eligible party, as the case may be, and the broadcaster or network operator.

In the period beginning on the issue of the writs for a general election and ending at midnight on the day before polling day at that election, every network operator shall, subject to the regulations made under the Broadcasting Act and to the conditions of its licence, make available, at no cost, to the registered parties and eligible parties referred to in subsection (2), for the transmission of political announcements and other programming produced by or on behalf of those parties, broadcasting time as determined under that subsection if the network formed and operated by the network operator

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: reaches a majority of Canadians whose mother tongue is the same as that in which the network broadcasts;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is licensed with respect to more than a particular series of programs or type of programming; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: does not involve a distribution undertaking as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Broadcasting Act.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of subsection (1), the minimum amount of broadcasting time that a network operator is to make available shall be no less than the amount of free broadcasting time made available by it at the last general election and shall be made available as follows:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: two minutes to every registered party referred to in paragraph 337(1)(a) and every eligible party referred to in paragraph 339(2)(a); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the remainder to all registered parties that have been allocated any of the broadcasting time to be made available under section 335 and all eligible parties that have requested broadcasting time under section 339 in the proportion that their allocated or requested purchasable broadcasting time bears to the total broadcasting time allocated or requested under those sections.

Subsection.Text: The value of free broadcasting time made available to a registered party under this section shall not be taken into consideration in calculating its election expenses within the meaning of section 376.
For the purpose of subsection (1), a network is deemed to reach

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: people resident within the areas served by broadcasting stations affiliated to the network that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of A.M. radio stations, are enclosed by the night-time interference-free official contour of the stations,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of F.M. radio stations, are enclosed by the 50 mV per metre official contour of the stations, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the case of television stations, are enclosed by the Grade B official contour of the stations; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: people resident outside the areas described in paragraph (a) to whom the signals of broadcasting stations affiliated to the network are available via distribution undertakings licensed by the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission.

Section.Text: The Broadcasting Arbitrator shall, not later than two days after the issue of the writs for a general election, prepare and send to the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission a set of guidelines respecting

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the allocation of or entitlement to broadcasting time under this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the procedures for booking broadcasting time by registered parties and eligible parties; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any other matters that may be pertinent to the conduct of broadcasters and network operators under this Act.

Section.MarginalNote: C.R.T.C. to prepare and send guidelines
Section.Text: The Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission shall, not later than four days after the issue of the writs for a general election, prepare a set of guidelines respecting the applicability of the Broadcasting Act and the regulations made under that Act to the conduct of broadcasters and network operators in relation to a general election and send them, together with the set of guidelines sent by the Broadcasting Arbitrator under section 346, to all broadcasters and network operators.
No person shall charge a registered party, any other political party or a candidate or a person acting on behalf of any of them,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a rate for broadcasting time made available to the party or candidate, in the period beginning on the issue of the writs and ending at midnight on the day before polling day, that exceeds the lowest rate charged by the person for an equal amount of equivalent time on the same facilities made available to any other person at any time within that period; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a rate for an advertisement in a periodical publication published or distributed and made public in the period referred to in paragraph (a) that exceeds the lowest rate charged by the person for an equal amount of equivalent advertising space in the same issue of the periodical publication or in any other issue of it that is published or distributed and made public in that period.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: automatic dialing-announcing device means any automatic equipment that has the capability to store or produce telephone numbers and that is used alone or in conjunction with other equipment to convey a pre-recorded or synthesized voice message to those telephone numbers.
call means any of the following types of calls that are made to telephone numbers:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: live voice calls;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: calls made by means of an automatic dialing-announcing device;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: calls that consist of a combination of the types of calls referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b).

Definition.Code: se="348.01",df="{calling service provider}{fournisseur de services d’appel}"

MarginalNote.Code: se="348.01",df="{calling service provider}{fournisseur de services d’appel}",m1=""
se="348.01",df="{calling service provider}{fournisseur de services d’appel}",m1=""

Definition.Text: calling service provider means a person or group that carries on a business whose activities include the making of calls for or on behalf of another person or group.
group means a registered party, registered association, unincorporated trade union, trade association or other group of persons acting together by mutual consent for a common purpose.
internal services means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to a group, the services provided by its members or employees, and those provided to it free of charge by any individual;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to a candidate, a nomination contestant or a third party who is an individual, the services provided by them personally or by their employees and those provided free of charge to the candidate, contestant or third party by any individual; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in relation to a third party that is a corporation, the services provided by its employees and those provided to it free of charge by any individual.

Definition.Text: official representative means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a registered party, its chief agent;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a registered association, its financial agent;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a candidate, their official agent;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a nomination contestant, their financial agent;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a registered third party, its financial agent;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an unregistered third party that is a corporation, the officer of the corporation who has signing authority for it; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an unregistered third party that is a group, a person who is responsible for the group.

Definition.Text: registered third party means a third party that is registered under section 353.
third party means a person or a group, other than a registered party, registered association, candidate or nomination contestant.

Definition.Code: se="348.01",df="{voter contact calling services}{services d’appels aux électeurs}"

MarginalNote.Code: se="348.01",df="{voter contact calling services}{services d’appels aux électeurs}",m1=""
se="348.01",df="{voter contact calling services}{services d’appels aux électeurs}",m1=""

Definition.Text: voter contact calling services means services involving the making of calls during an election period for any purpose related to an election, including

Paragraph.Code: se="348.01",df="{voter contact calling services}{services d’appels aux électeurs}",p1="a"
Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: promoting or opposing a registered party, its leader, a candidate or a nomination contestant or any position on an issue with which such a party or person is associated;

Paragraph.Code: se="348.01",df="{voter contact calling services}{services d’appels aux électeurs}",p1="b"
Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: encouraging electors to vote or to refrain from voting;

Paragraph.Code: se="348.01",df="{voter contact calling services}{services d’appels aux électeurs}",p1="c"
Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: providing information about the election, including information about voting hours and the location of polling stations;

Paragraph.Code: se="348.01",df="{voter contact calling services}{services d’appels aux électeurs}",p1="d"
Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: gathering information about how electors voted in past elections or will vote in the election or their views on a registered party, its leader, a candidate or a nomination contestant or any issue with which such a party or person is associated; and

Paragraph.Code: se="348.01",df="{voter contact calling services}{services d’appels aux électeurs}",p1="e"
Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: raising funds for a registered party, a registered association, a candidate or a nomination contestant.

Heading.Label: DIVISION 1.1
Heading.TitleText: Provision of Voter Contact Calling Services
Agreements Relating to Voter Contact Calling Services

Section.MarginalNote: Prohibition — entering into agreement with calling service provider
Section.Text: A person or group shall not enter into an agreement with a calling service provider for voter contact calling services unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person or group is a registered party, a registered association, a nomination contestant or a registered third party, or an unregistered third party that is a corporation or group, and the agreement is entered into on behalf of the person or group by the person’s or group’s official representative;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person is a candidate and the agreement is entered into in their own name or on their behalf by their official representative or by a person that their official representative has so authorized in writing; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person is an unregistered third party who is an individual and the agreement is entered into in their own name.

Section.Text: Before a person enters into an agreement with a calling service provider for voter contact calling services, either in their own name or on behalf of another person or a group, the person shall inform the calling service provider that the agreement is for voter contact calling services and shall provide the calling service provider with their name, address and telephone number and a copy of a piece of identification authorized by the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission that contains their name.

Subsection.Text: Before a calling service provider enters into an agreement with a person or group to provide voter contact calling services, the calling service provider shall obtain from the person who is to enter into the agreement, either in their own name or on behalf of the person or a group, their name, address and telephone number and a copy of a piece of identification authorized by the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission that contains their name.
The calling service provider shall prepare a record of the information obtained and keep that record and the copy of the piece of identification for one year after the end of the election period.

Section.MarginalNote: Obligation to confirm nature of services

Subsection.Text: A calling service provider that enters into an agreement to make calls for or on behalf of a person or group shall, before the first call is made under the agreement during an election period, ask the person or group whether the making of calls under the agreement would constitute voter contact calling services.

If the making of calls under the agreement does constitute voter contact calling services, a person who is authorized under section 348.02 to enter into an agreement for voter contact calling services with respect to the person or group in question shall, before the first call is made, authorize the provision of voter contact calling services under the agreement and provide the calling service provider with their name, address and telephone number and a copy of a piece of identification authorized by the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission that contains their name.

If the making of calls under the agreement does constitute voter contact calling services, the calling service provider shall, before the first call is made, obtain from the person who provides the authorization in accordance with subsection (2) that person’s name, address and telephone number and a copy of a piece of identification authorized by the Commission that contains that person’s name.
The calling service provider shall prepare a record of the information obtained and keep that record and the copy of the piece of identification for one year after the end of the election period.

A calling service provider that, in accordance with an agreement, provides voter contact calling services shall file a registration notice with the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission.
For each election period to which the agreement applies, the registration notice shall be filed not later than 48 hours after the first call is made under the agreement and shall set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the calling service provider’s name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person or group with which the calling service provider has entered into the agreement; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the type of calls to be made under the agreement.

Section.MarginalNote: Obligation to file registration notice — agreement

Subsection.Text: A person who enters into an agreement with a calling service provider for voter contact calling services, either in their own name or on behalf of another person or a group, or a person who provides an authorization of the provision of voter contact calling services under an agreement in accordance with subsection 348.05(2), as the case may be, shall file a registration notice with the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission.
For each election period to which the agreement applies, the registration notice shall be filed not later than 48 hours after the first call is made under the agreement and shall set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the calling service provider’s name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person or group with which the calling service provider has entered into the agreement; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the type of calls to be made under the agreement.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Obligation to provide copy of identification document
Subsection.Text: The person who files the registration notice shall, at the time of filing the registration notice, provide the Commission with their name, address and telephone number and a copy of a piece of identification authorized by the Commission that contains their name.

Except for the purposes of section 348.12, a registration notice is deemed not to have been filed if the information and the copy of the piece of identification are not provided at the time the registration notice is filed.

Section.MarginalNote: Obligation to file registration notice — live voice calls

Subsection.Text: If, during an election period, a third party that is a corporation or group uses its internal services to make live voice calls for any purpose relating to the election, including a purpose referred to in any of paragraphs (a) to (e) of the definition voter contact calling services in section 348.01, the third party’s official representative shall file a registration notice with the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission.
The registration notice shall be filed not later than 48 hours after the first live voice call is made and shall set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the third party’s name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address and telephone number of the official representative; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement that the third party is making live voice calls.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Obligation to provide copy of identification document
Subsection.Text: The official representative shall, at the time of filing the registration notice, provide the Commission with their name, address and telephone number and a copy of a piece of identification authorized by the Commission that contains their name.

Except for the purposes of section 348.12, a registration notice is deemed not to have been filed if the information and the copy of the piece of identification are not provided at the time the registration notice is filed.

Section.MarginalNote: Obligation to file registration notice — other calls

Subsection.Text: If, during an election period, a person or group uses their internal services to make calls by means of an automatic dialing-announcing device for any purpose relating to the election, including a purpose referred to in any of paragraphs (a) to (e) of the definition voter contact calling services in section 348.01, the official representative of the person or group — or the person themselves, if the person is an unregistered third party who is an individual — shall file a registration notice with the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission.
The registration notice shall be filed not later than 48 hours after the first call is made and shall set out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the person or group;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address and telephone number of the official representative or individual; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a statement that the person or group is making calls by means of an automatic dialing-announcing device.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Obligation to provide copy of identification document
Subsection.Text: The official representative or individual shall, at the time of filing the registration notice, provide the Commission with their name, address and telephone number and a copy of a piece of identification authorized by the Commission that contains their name.

Except for the purposes of section 348.12, a registration notice is deemed not to have been filed if the information and the copy of the piece of identification are not provided at the time the registration notice is filed.

Heading.TitleText: Role of the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission

Subsection.Text: The Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission is responsible for the administration and enforcement of this Division.
The administration and enforcement of this Division are to be carried out under Part V of the Telecommunications Act.

Section.Text: The Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission is responsible for establishing and maintaining a registry, to be known as the Voter Contact Registry, in which all documents provided to it under sections 348.06 to 348.09 are to be kept.

As soon as feasible after the expiry of 30 days after polling day, the Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission shall, in the manner that it considers appropriate, publish the registration notices relating to the election that have been filed with it.

Subsection.Text: The Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission may, in writing and on any terms it specifies, delegate to any person any of the powers, duties and functions referred to in sections 348.11 and 348.12.
The Commission may, in writing, revoke a delegation made under subsection (1).

Section.Text: The Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission may authorize the types of pieces of identification and of copies of such pieces of identification for the purposes of sections 348.03 to 348.05 and 348.07 to 348.09.

The Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission shall, on the request of the Commissioner, disclose to the Commissioner any document or information that it received under this Division that the Commissioner considers necessary for the purpose of ensuring compliance with and enforcement of this Act, other than this Division.
Every calling service provider that, in accordance with an agreement, provides voter contact calling services shall keep, for three years after the end of the election period,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of each unique script used in live voice calls made under the agreement and a record of every date on which the script was used; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a recording of each unique message conveyed by an automatic dialing-announcing device that is used to make calls under the agreement and a record of every date on which it was so conveyed.

Section.Text: Every person or group that enters into an agreement with a calling service provider under which voter contact calling services are provided shall keep, for one year after the end of the election period,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a copy of each unique script used in live voice calls made under the agreement and a record of every date on which the script was used; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a recording of each unique message conveyed by an automatic dialing-announcing device that is used to make calls under the agreement and a record of every date on which it was so conveyed.

Section.Text: If, during an election period, a person or group uses their internal services to make calls by means of an automatic dialing-announcing device for any purpose relating to the election, including a purpose referred to in any of paragraphs (a) to (e) of the definition voter contact calling services in section 348.01, the person or group shall keep a recording of each unique message conveyed by the device and a record of every date on which it was so conveyed, for one year after the end of the election period.

Section.MarginalNote: Third party that is corporation or group — internal services
Section.Text: If, during an election period, a third party that is a corporation or group uses its internal services to make live voice calls for any purpose relating to the election, including a purpose referred to in any of paragraphs (a) to (e) of the definition voter contact calling services in section 348.01, the third party shall, if a script is used, keep a copy of each unique script used and a record of every date on which the script was used, for one year after the end of the election period.
The definitions in this section apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: election advertising has the same meaning as in section 319.

Definition.Code: se="349",df="{election advertising expense}{dépenses de publicité électorale}"

MarginalNote.Code: se="349",df="{election advertising expense}{dépenses de publicité électorale}",m1=""
se="349",df="{election advertising expense}{dépenses de publicité électorale}",m1=""

Definition.Text: election advertising expense means an expense incurred in relation to

Paragraph.Code: se="349",df="{election advertising expense}{dépenses de publicité électorale}",p1="a"
Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the production of an election advertising message; and

Paragraph.Code: se="349",df="{election advertising expense}{dépenses de publicité électorale}",p1="b"
Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the acquisition of the means of transmission to the public of an election advertising message.

Definition.Text: expenses means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: amounts paid;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: liabilities incurred;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the commercial value of property and services, other than volunteer labour, that are donated or provided; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: amounts that represent the difference between an amount paid or a liability incurred for property and services, other than volunteer labour, and the commercial value of the property and services, when they are provided at less than their commercial value.

Definition.Text: group means an unincorporated trade union, trade association or other group of persons acting together by mutual consent for a common purpose.
third party means a person or a group, other than a candidate, registered party or electoral district association of a registered party.

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 351.1, a third party shall not incur election advertising expenses of a total amount of more than $150,000 in relation to a general election.
Not more than $3,000 of the total amount referred to in subsection (1) shall be incurred to promote or oppose the election of one or more candidates in a given electoral district, including by

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: naming them;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: showing their likenesses;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: identifying them by their respective political affiliations; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: taking a position on an issue with which they are particularly associated.

Subsection.Text: The limit set out in subsection (2) only applies to an amount incurred with respect to a leader of a registered party or eligible party to the extent that it is incurred to promote or oppose his or her election in a given electoral district.
Subject to section 351.1, a third party shall not incur election advertising expenses of a total amount of more than $3,000 in a given electoral district in relation to a by-election.

If a general election is held on a date other than one set out in subsection 56.1(2) or section 56.2, or if a by-election is held, a third party does not incur an election advertising expense if, on the issue of the writ or writs, it is not able to cancel the transmission of that advertising.
The amounts referred to in subsections (1), (2) and (4) shall be multiplied by the inflation adjustment factor referred to in section 384 that is in effect on the issue of the writ or writs.
If an election period is longer than 37 days, then the amounts referred to in subsections (1), (2) and (4) are increased by adding to them the product of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one thirty-seventh of the amount referred to in subsection (1), (2) or (4), as the case may be, and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the number of days in the election period minus 37.

Section.Text: A third party shall not circumvent, or attempt to circumvent, a limit set out in section 350 in any manner, including by splitting itself into two or more third parties for the purpose of circumventing the limit or acting in collusion with another third party so that their combined election advertising expenses exceed the limit.

A third party shall not incur election advertising expenses of a total amount of $500 or more in relation to a general election or a by-election, or, if the election periods of two or more by-elections overlap with each other in whole or in part, in relation to those by-elections, unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the third party is an individual, the individual

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is a Canadian citizen,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is a permanent resident as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: resides in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the third party is a corporation, it carries on business in Canada; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if the third party is a group, a person who is responsible for the group

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is a Canadian citizen,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is a permanent resident as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: resides in Canada.

Section.Text: For greater certainty, for the purposes of subsections 350(1) and (4) and section 351.1 if election advertising is transmitted during an election period, it shall be considered an election advertising expense, regardless of when it was incurred.
A third party shall identify itself in any election advertising placed by it and indicate that it has authorized the advertising.

Subsection.Text: Subject to section 351.1, a third party shall register immediately after having incurred election advertising expenses of a total amount of $500 and may not register before the issue of the writ.
An application for registration shall be sent to the Chief Electoral Officer in the prescribed form and shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the third party is an individual, the individual’s name, address and telephone number, their signature and their certification that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: they are a Canadian citizen,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: they are a permanent resident as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: they reside in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the third party is a corporation, the name, address and telephone number of the corporation and of an officer who has signing authority for it, the officer’s signature and their certification that the corporation carries on business in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (b.1)
Paragraph.Text: if the third party is a group, the name, address and telephone number of the group and of a person who is responsible for the group, the person’s signature and their certification that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: they are a Canadian citizen,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: they are a permanent resident as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: they reside in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the address and telephone number of the office of the third party where its books and records are kept and of the office to which communications may be addressed; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name, address and telephone number of the third party’s financial agent.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Declaration of financial agent to accompany application
Subsection.Text: An application under subsection (2) must be accompanied by a declaration signed by the financial agent accepting the appointment.

If a third party’s financial agent is replaced, it shall, without delay, provide the Chief Electoral Officer with the new financial agent’s name, address and telephone number and a declaration signed by the new financial agent accepting the appointment.

If the third party is a trade union, corporation or other entity with a governing body, the application must include a copy of the resolution passed by its governing body authorizing it to incur election advertising expenses.

The Chief Electoral Officer shall, without delay after receiving an application, determine whether the requirements set out in subsections (1) to (3) and (5) are met and shall then notify the person who signed the application whether the third party is registered. In the case of a refusal to register, the Chief Electoral Officer shall give reasons for the refusal.

A third party may not be registered under a name that, in the opinion of the Chief Electoral Officer, is likely to be confused with the name of a candidate, registered party, registered third party or eligible party.

The registration of a third party is valid only for the election period during which the application is made, but the third party continues to be subject to the requirement to file an election advertising report under subsection 359(1).

A third party that is required to register under subsection 353(1) shall appoint a financial agent who may be a person who is authorized to sign an application for registration made under that subsection.
The following persons are not eligible to be a financial agent of a third party:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a candidate or an official agent of a candidate;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person who is the chief agent, or a registered agent, of a registered party;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an election officer or an employee of a returning officer; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a person who is not a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident within the meaning of subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

Subsection.Text: A third party that incurs election advertising expenses in an aggregate amount of $5,000 or more must appoint an auditor without delay.
The following are eligible to be an auditor for a third party:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a person who is a member in good standing of a corporation, an association or an institute of professional accountants; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a partnership every partner of which is a member in good standing of a corporation, an association or an institute of professional accountants.

Subsection.Text: The following persons are not eligible to be an auditor for a third party:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the third party’s financial agent;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a person who signed the application made under subsection 353(2);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an election officer;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a candidate;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the official agent of a candidate;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the chief agent of a registered party or an eligible party; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: a registered agent of a registered party.

Subsection.Text: Every third party, without delay after an auditor is appointed, must provide the Chief Electoral Officer with the auditor’s name, address, telephone number and occupation and a signed declaration accepting the appointment.

If a third party’s auditor is replaced, it must, without delay, provide the Chief Electoral Officer with the new auditor’s name, address, telephone number and occupation and a signed declaration accepting the appointment.

Section.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall maintain, for the period that he or she considers appropriate, a registry of third parties in which is recorded, in relation to each third party, the information referred to in subsections 353(2) and 355(4) and (5).

Section.MarginalNote: Authorization by financial agent for expenses, etc.

Subsection.Text: Every contribution made during an election period to a registered third party for election advertising purposes must be accepted by, and every election advertising expense incurred on behalf of a third party must be authorized by, its financial agent.
A financial agent may authorize a person to accept contributions or incur election advertising expenses, but that authorization does not limit the responsibility of the financial agent.

No third party shall use a contribution for election advertising if the third party does not know the name and address of the contributor or is otherwise unable to determine within which class of contributor referred to in subsection 359(6) they fall.

Section.Text: No third party shall use a contribution for election advertising purposes if the contribution is from

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a person who is not a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident within the meaning of subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a corporation or an association that does not carry on business in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a trade union that does not hold bargaining rights for employees in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a foreign political party; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a foreign government or an agent of one.

Subsection.Text: Every third party that is required to be registered in accordance with subsection 353(1) shall file an election advertising report in the prescribed form with the Chief Electoral Officer within four months after polling day.
An election advertising report shall contain

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a general election,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a list of election advertising expenses referred to in subsection 350(2) and the time and place of the broadcast or publication of the advertisements to which the expenses relate, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: a list of all election advertising expenses other than those referred to in subparagraph (i) and the time and place of broadcast or publication of the advertisements to which the expenses relate; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a by-election, a list of election advertising expenses referred to in subsection 350(4) and the time and place of the broadcast or publication of the advertisements to which the expenses relate.

Subsection.Text: If a third party has not incurred expenses referred to in paragraph (2)(a) or (b), that fact shall be indicated in its election advertising report.
The election advertising report shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the amount, by class of contributor, of contributions for election advertising purposes that were received in the period beginning six months before the issue of the writ and ending on polling day;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for each contributor who made contributions of a total amount of more than $200 for election advertising purposes during the period referred to in paragraph (a), subject to paragraph (b.1), their name, address and class, and the amount and date of each contribution;

Paragraph.Label: (b.1)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a numbered company that is a contributor referred to in paragraph (b), the name of the chief executive officer or president of that company; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the amount, other than an amount of a contribution referred to in paragraph (a), that was paid out of the third party’s own funds for election advertising expenses.

Subsection.Text: For the purpose of subsection (4), a contribution includes a loan.
For the purposes of paragraphs (4)(a) and (b), the following are the classes of contributor:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: individuals;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: businesses;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: commercial organizations;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: governments;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: trade unions;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: corporations without share capital other than trade unions; and

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: unincorporated organizations or associations other than trade unions.

Subsection.Text: If the third party is unable to identify which contributions were received for election advertising purposes in the period referred to in paragraph (4)(a), it must list, subject to paragraph (4)(b.1), the names and addresses of every contributor who donated a total of more than $200 to it during that period.

An election advertising report shall include the signed declarations of the financial agent and, if different, of the person who signed the application made under subsection 353(2) that the report is accurate.

A third party shall, at the request of the Chief Electoral Officer, provide the original of any bill, voucher or receipt in relation to an election advertising expense that is in an amount of more than $50.
The election advertising report of a third party that incurs $5,000 or more in election advertising expenses must include a report made under subsection (2).

The third party’s auditor shall report on the election advertising report and shall make any examination that will enable the auditor to give an opinion in the report as to whether the election advertising report presents fairly the information contained in the accounting records on which it is based.
An auditor shall include in the report any statement that the auditor considers necessary, when

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the election advertising report that is the subject of the auditor’s report does not present fairly the information contained in the accounting records on which it is based;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the auditor has not received from the third party all of the required information and explanation; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: based on the auditor’s examination, it appears that proper accounting records have not been kept by the third party.

Subsection.Text: The auditor shall have access at any reasonable time to all of the documents of the third party, and may require the third party to provide any information or explanation, that, in the auditor’s opinion, is necessary to enable the auditor to prepare the report.

Section.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer may make a correction in a report referred to in subsection 359(1) if the error does not materially affect the substance of the report.
The Chief Electoral Officer shall, in the manner he or she considers appropriate,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: publish the names and addresses of registered third parties, as they are registered; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: publish, within one year after the issue of the writ, reports made under subsection 359(1).

Subsection.Text: No person or entity other than an individual who is a Canadian citizen or is a permanent resident as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act shall make a contribution to a registered party, a registered association, a nomination contestant, a candidate or a leadership contestant.

If a registered party, a registered association, a nomination contestant, a candidate or a leadership contestant receives a contribution from an ineligible contributor, the chief agent of the registered party, the financial agent of the registered association, the official agent of the candidate or the financial agent of the nomination contestant or leadership contestant, as the case may be, shall, within 30 days after becoming aware of the ineligibility, return the contribution unused to the contributor or, if that is not possible, pay the amount of it — or, in the case of a non-monetary contribution, an amount of money equal to its commercial value — to the Chief Electoral Officer, who shall forward that amount to the Receiver General.

For greater certainty, contributions to and expenses of a provincial division of a registered party are contributions to and expenses of the party. Similarly, transfers of funds to or by the division are transfers to or by the party.

A provincial division of a registered party may appoint registered agents, subject to any terms and conditions that the appointment specifies. This Act applies to those agents as if they were registered agents appointed by the party under subsection 396(1).
Any money that is used for a nomination contestant’s, a candidate’s or a leadership contestant’s campaign out of their own funds is a contribution for the purposes of this Act.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exclusion for goods and services — registered parties, registered associations and candidates
Subsection.Text: A provision of goods or services is permitted and is not a contribution for the purposes of this Act if it is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: from a registered party to an electoral district association of the party or a candidate endorsed by the party;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: from a registered association to the registered party with which it is affiliated, another registered association of the party or a candidate endorsed by the party;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: from a registered party or registered association to a nomination contestant or a leadership contestant in compliance with subsection 365(1);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: from a candidate endorsed by a registered party to the party or a registered association of the party;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: from a candidate to themselves in their capacity as a nomination contestant in respect of the same election; or

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: in the case where a writ is deemed to be withdrawn under subsection 31(3) of the Parliament of Canada Act, from a candidate in an election that is cancelled to themselves in their capacity as a candidate in respect of the general election resulting from the dissolution of Parliament.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exclusion for funds — registered parties, registered associations and candidates
Subsection.Text: A transfer of funds is permitted and is not a contribution for the purposes of this Act if it is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: from a registered party to an electoral district association of the party;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: from a registered association to the registered party with which it is affiliated or another registered association of the party;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: from a candidate endorsed by a registered party to the party or a registered association of the party;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: from a candidate to themselves in their capacity as a nomination contestant in respect of the same election; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case where a writ is deemed to be withdrawn under subsection 31(3) of the Parliament of Canada Act, from a candidate in an election that is cancelled to themselves in their capacity as a candidate in respect of the general election resulting from the dissolution of Parliament.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exclusion for funds other than trust funds — registered parties and registered associations
Subsection.Text: A transfer of funds, other than trust funds, is permitted and is not a contribution for the purposes of this Act if it is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: from a registered party to a candidate endorsed by the party; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: from a registered association to a candidate endorsed by the registered party with which the association is affiliated.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exclusion for funds — nomination contestants, leadership contestants and registered parties
Subsection.Text: A transfer of funds is permitted and is not a contribution for the purposes of this Act if it is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: from a nomination contestant of a registered party to the party, the registered association of the party that held the nomination contest or the official agent of the candidate endorsed by the party in the electoral district in which the nomination contest was held;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: from a leadership contestant of a registered party to the party or a registered association of the party; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: from a registered party to a leadership contestant out of funds from a directed contribution referred to in subsection 365(3).

Subsection.Text: The provision by an employer of a paid leave of absence to an employee for the purpose of allowing the employee to be a nomination contestant or candidate is not a contribution.
The payment by an individual during a year of fees of not more than $25 per year for a period of not more than five years for membership in a registered party is not a contribution.

For greater certainty, the payment by or on behalf of an individual of fees to attend an annual or biennial convention or leadership convention of a particular registered party is a contribution to that party.

No registered party and no electoral district association of a registered party shall provide goods or services or transfer funds to a nomination contestant or a leadership contestant, unless the goods or services are offered equally to all contestants.

In this section, directed contribution means an amount that is all or part of a contribution made to a registered party and that the contributor requests in writing be transferred to a particular leadership contestant.

Subsection (1) does not apply to a directed contribution that is transferred by the registered party to the leadership contestant mentioned in the request if the party provides, with the amount transferred, a statement in the prescribed form setting out the name and address of the contributor, the amount and date of the contribution, the amount of the directed contribution, the amount that the party is transferring and the date of the transfer.
The amount of a directed contribution that is to be transferred to a leadership contestant is deemed to be a contribution made by the contributor to the contestant.

Any person who is authorized to accept contributions on behalf of a registered party, a registered association, a nomination contestant, a candidate or a leadership contestant shall issue a receipt — of which the person shall keep a copy — for each contribution of more than $20 that they accept.

If anonymous contributions of $20 or less per person are collected in response to a general solicitation at a meeting or fundraising event related to the affairs of a registered party, a registered association, a nomination contestant, a candidate or a leadership contestant, the person authorized to accept those contributions shall record the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the function at which the contributions were collected;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the date of the function;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the approximate number of people at the function; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the total amount of the anonymous contributions received.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection 373(4), no individual shall make contributions that exceed

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: $1,500 in total in any calendar year to a particular registered party;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: $1,500 in total in any calendar year to the registered associations, nomination contestants and candidates of a particular registered party;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: $1,500 in total to a candidate for a particular election who is not the candidate of a registered party; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: $1,500 in total in any calendar year to the leadership contestants in a particular leadership contest.

Subsection.Text: The contribution limits set out in subsection (1) increase by $25 on January 1 in each year.

A contribution may be made by way of a testamentary disposition if the contribution is made only in one calendar year and does not cause the contributor to exceed the relevant limit under subsection (1), taking into account any contributions that the contributor made before their death.

A testamentary disposition that provides for a contribution that would cause the contributor to exceed the relevant limit under subsection (1) shall be read as if the contribution is for the highest amount that would not cause the contributor to exceed that limit, and a testamentary disposition that provides for a contribution to be made in more than one calendar year after the year in which this subsection comes into force shall be read as if the contribution is to be made only in the first of those calendar years.

For the purposes of subsection (1), a contribution to a person who presents themselves as seeking the endorsement of a particular registered party is to be treated as a contribution referred to in paragraph (1)(b) to a candidate of that party and a contribution to a person who presents themselves as seeking to be a candidate not endorsed by any registered party is to be treated as a contribution referred to in paragraph (1)(c).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exception — nomination contestant’s contributions to own campaign
Subsection.Text: Contributions that do not exceed $1,000 in total by a nomination contestant out of their own funds to their own campaign as a nomination contestant do not count towards the nomination contestant’s contributions for the purposes of paragraph (1)(b).

Subject to subsection (7), no candidate in a particular election and no leadership contestant in a particular leadership contest shall make a contribution out of their own funds to their own campaign.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exception — certain contributions to own campaign
Subsection.Text: The following contributions are permitted:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: contributions that do not exceed $5,000 in total by a candidate for a particular election out of their own funds to their own campaign; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: contributions that do not exceed $25,000 in total by a leadership contestant in a particular leadership contest out of their own funds to their own campaign.

Subsection.Text: Contributions made under subsection (7) do not have the effect of reducing the amounts that the candidate or leadership contestant, as the case may be, may contribute under subsection (1) to other candidates or to other leadership contestants, as the case may be.
No person or entity shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: circumvent, or attempt to circumvent, the prohibition under subsection 363(1) or 367(6) or a limit set out in subsection 367(1) or (7) or section 371; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: act in collusion with another person or entity for that purpose.

Subsection.Text: No person or entity shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: conceal, or attempt to conceal, the identity of the source of a contribution governed by this Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: act in collusion with another person or entity for that purpose.

Subsection.Text: No person who is permitted to accept contributions under this Act shall knowingly accept a contribution that exceeds a limit under this Act.

No person or entity shall enter into an agreement for the provision for payment of goods or services, directly or indirectly, to a registered party or a candidate that includes a term that any individual will make a contribution, directly or indirectly, to a registered party, a registered association, a nomination contestant, a candidate or a leadership contestant.

No person or entity shall solicit or accept a contribution on behalf of a registered party, a registered association or a candidate if the person or entity makes a representation to the contributor or potential contributor that part or all of the contribution would be transferred to a person or entity other than the registered party or a candidate, a leadership contestant or an electoral district association.
No person or entity shall act in collusion with another person or entity for the purpose of circumventing the prohibition under subsection (1).

No individual shall make a contribution to a registered party, a registered association, a nomination contestant, a candidate or a leadership contestant that comes from money, property or the services of any person or entity that was provided to that individual for that purpose.

Despite subsection (1), a candidate or a leadership contestant may make a contribution under subsection 367(7) that comes from money provided by way of a loan to the candidate or leadership contestant made in writing by a financial institution as defined in section 2 of the Bank Act at a fair market rate of interest, as long as no security is given for the loan except property of the candidate or leadership contestant, as the case may be.

Section.Text: No individual shall, in respect of each contribution made under this Division, contribute cash in an amount that exceeds $20.

If a registered party, a registered association, a nomination contestant, a candidate or a leadership contestant receives a contribution made in contravention of subsection 367(1) or 368(4) or section 370 or 371, the chief agent of the registered party, the financial agent of the registered association, the official agent of the candidate or the financial agent of the nomination contestant or leadership contestant, as the case may be, shall, within 30 days after becoming aware of the contravention, return the contribution unused to the contributor or, if that is not possible, pay the amount of it — or, in the case of a non-monetary contribution, an amount of money equal to its commercial value — to the Chief Electoral Officer, who shall forward that amount to the Receiver General.

Subsection.Text: Except as permitted under this section, no person or entity shall

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: make a loan to a registered party or a registered association;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: make a loan to a nomination contestant, a candidate or a leadership contestant in relation to the contestant’s or candidate’s campaign; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: guarantee a loan referred to in paragraph (a) or (b).

Subsection.Text: Except if the loan is permitted under this section, no registered agent of a registered party and no financial agent of a registered association shall borrow money on behalf of the party or association, and no official agent of a candidate and no financial agent of a nomination contestant or of a leadership contestant shall borrow money for the purposes of the candidate’s or contestant’s campaign.
A financial institution as defined in section 2 of the Bank Act may in writing make a loan referred to in subsection (1) at a fair market rate of interest.

An individual who is a Canadian citizen or is a permanent resident as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act may in writing make a loan referred to in subsection (1) or guarantee such a loan. However, the total of the following amounts shall not at any time exceed the individual’s relevant contribution limit set out in paragraphs 367(1)(a) to (d), subsection 367(5) and paragraphs 367(7)(a) and (b):

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the amounts of the individual’s contributions,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the amounts of the individual’s loans made in the relevant contribution period, not including any amount that has been repaid in the calendar year in which the loan was made, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the amounts guaranteed by the individual in the relevant contribution period, not including any amount for which the individual has ceased to be liable in the calendar year in which the guarantee was given.

Subsection.Text: A loan may be made in writing

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by a registered party to a registered association of the party or a candidate endorsed by the party; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by a registered association to the registered party with which it is affiliated, another registered association of the party or a candidate endorsed by the party.

Subsection.Text: A registered party or registered association may in writing guarantee a loan made in writing to a party, association or candidate to which it itself is permitted to make a loan under subsection (5).

Section.Text: No individual shall make a loan to a registered party, a registered association, a nomination contestant, a candidate or a leadership contestant that is made possible by money, property or the services of any person or entity that was provided to that individual for that purpose.
An electoral campaign expense of a candidate is an expense reasonably incurred as an incidence of the election, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an election expense;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a personal expense; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any fees of the candidate’s auditor, and any costs incurred for a recount of votes cast in the candidate’s electoral district, that have not been reimbursed by the Receiver General.

Subsection.Text: An election expense is any of the following:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any cost incurred, or non-monetary contribution received, by a registered party or a candidate, to the extent that the property or service that the cost was incurred for or that was received as a non-monetary contribution is used to directly promote or oppose a registered party, its leader or a candidate during an election period; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any acceptance by a registered party or a candidate of a provision of goods or services that is permitted under subsection 364(2), to the extent that the goods or services are used to directly promote or oppose a registered party, its leader or a candidate during an election period.

Subsection.Text: Expenses for a fundraising activity and expenses to directly promote the nomination of a person as a candidate or the selection of a person as leader of a registered party, other than expenses referred to in paragraphs (3)(a) and (b) that are related to such fundraising and promotional activities, are not election expenses under subsection (1).
An election expense referred to in subsection (1) includes a cost incurred for, a non-monetary contribution in relation to, or a provision of goods and services in relation to,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the production of advertising or promotional material;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the distribution, broadcast or publication of such material in any media or by any other means during the election period, including by the use of a capital asset;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the payment of remuneration and expenses to or on behalf of a person for their services as an official agent or registered agent or in any other capacity;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: securing a meeting space or the supply of light refreshments at meetings;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: any product or service provided by a government, a Crown corporation or any other public agency; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the conduct of election surveys or other surveys or research during an election period.

Subsection.Text: In subsection (1), cost incurred means an expense that is incurred by a registered party or a candidate, whether it is paid or unpaid.

Section.Text: If a fundraising activity is held for the primary purpose of soliciting a monetary contribution for a registered party, a registered association, a nomination contestant, a candidate or a leadership contestant by way of selling a ticket, the amount of the monetary contribution received is the difference between the price of the ticket and the fair market value of what the ticket entitles the bearer to obtain.

Subsection.Text: A candidate’s personal expenses include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: travel and living expenses;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: childcare expenses;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: expenses relating to the provision of care for a person with a physical or mental incapacity for whom the candidate normally provides such care; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a candidate who has a disability, additional expenses that are related to the disability.

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer may establish categories of personal expenses and fix maximum amounts that may be incurred for expenses in each category.

Section.Text: Any expenses of a candidate that are incurred to remunerate the candidate’s representatives referred to in subsection 136(1) or 237.1(2) are deemed to be personal expenses of the candidate.

Subsection.Text: If an expense of $50 or more was incurred under this Act by or on behalf of a registered party, a registered association, a nomination contestant, a candidate or a leadership contestant and paid by an agent or other person authorized under this Act to pay such an expense, the agent or other person shall keep a copy of the invoice prepared by the person who provided the good or service to which the expense relates setting out the nature of the expense together with proof that it was paid.

If an expense of less than $50 was incurred and paid as described in subsection (1), the person who made the payment shall keep a record of the nature of the expense together with proof that it was paid.
A person may pay a petty expense incurred for office supplies, postage, courier services and other incidental expenses under the written authorization of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a registered agent of a registered party, as an expense incurred on behalf of the registered party;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an electoral district agent of a registered association, as an expense incurred on behalf of the association;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the financial agent of a nomination contestant, as a nomination campaign expense;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the official agent of a candidate, as an electoral campaign expense for the candidate; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a leadership campaign agent of a leadership contestant, as a leadership campaign expense.

Subsection.Text: The written authorization referred to in subsection (1) shall specify a maximum amount for the total of petty expenses that the person is authorized to pay.

A person who is authorized to pay a petty expense shall provide the agent who authorized it with a statement of payments that the person made and the documentation referred to in section 380 within three months after

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a petty expense incurred on behalf of a registered party, the day on which it is incurred;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a petty expense incurred on behalf of a registered association, the day on which it is incurred;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a petty expense incurred on behalf of a nomination contestant, the day on which it is incurred;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a petty expense incurred on behalf of a candidate, polling day; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a petty expense incurred on behalf of a leadership contestant, the day on which it is incurred.

Subsection.Text: No person who is authorized to pay petty expenses shall pay, in total, more than the maximum amount of petty expenses that they are authorized to pay.

Section.MarginalNote: Publication of electoral campaign returns and election expenses returns

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall, in the manner that he or she considers appropriate, publish the original election expenses returns of registered parties and electoral campaign returns of candidates and any corrected or revised versions of those returns

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an original return, within one year after the issue of a writ for an election;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a corrected or revised version of a return, as soon as feasible after he or she receives it; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a document referred to in subsection 477.59(10), (11), (12) or (15), or a corrected or revised version of such a document, as soon as feasible after he or she receives it.

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall publish the following, as soon as feasible after receiving them, in the manner that he or she considers appropriate:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the financial transactions returns of registered parties and registered associations, and any corrected or revised versions of those returns;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the nomination campaign returns of nomination contestants, any document referred to in subsection 476.75(10), (11), (12) or (15), and any corrected or revised versions of those returns or documents; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the leadership campaign returns of leadership contestants, any document referred to in subsection 478.8(10), (11), (12) or (15), any corrected or revised versions of those returns or documents, the returns in respect of contributions required under section 478.81, and any statements containing information with respect to contributions referred to in paragraph 478.3(2)(d).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Summary of return on candidates’ election expenses
Subsection.Text: As soon as feasible after receiving an electoral campaign return, any document referred to in subsection 477.59(10), (11), (12) or (15) or any corrected or revised version of those returns or documents for each candidate in an electoral district, the Chief Electoral Officer shall, in the manner that he or she considers appropriate, publish a summary report that includes the maximum election expenses allowed for the electoral district and, for each candidate,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the total election expenses;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the total personal expenses;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the number of contributors and the total amount of contributions received;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the official agent;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the auditor; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: if applicable, an indication that the auditor’s report on a return was qualified.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Publication of return of deregistered parties
Subsection.Text: As soon as feasible after receiving a financial transactions return under subparagraph 420(a)(i) from a deregistered political party, the Chief Electoral Officer shall publish it in the manner that he or she considers appropriate.

The Chief Electoral Officer shall, as soon as feasible after receiving the documents referred to in subsection 477.59(1) for an electoral district, deliver a copy of them to the returning officer for the electoral district.

A registered party and an eligible party shall include with the statement or report referred to in subsection (1) a statement certified by its chief agent that sets out the names of the person or persons who are authorized by the party to endorse prospective candidates at a general election.

A returning officer who receives documents under subsection (1) shall retain them for three years, or any shorter period that the Chief Electoral Officer considers appropriate, after the end of the six-month period mentioned in subsection (2).

Section.Text: Before April 1 in each year, the Chief Electoral Officer shall cause to be published in the Canada Gazette an inflation adjustment factor that is in effect for a period of one year beginning on that date. It shall be a fraction with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a numerator that is the annual average Consumer Price Index, as published by Statistics Canada under the authority of the Statistics Act, for the calendar year immediately before that date, calculated on the basis of 1992 being equal to 100; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a denominator that is 108.6, which is the annual average Consumer Price Index, as published by Statistics Canada under the authority of the Statistics Act, for 1998, calculated on the basis of 1992 being equal to 100.

Subsection.Text: The leader of a political party may apply to the Chief Electoral Officer for the political party to become a registered party.
The application for registration shall include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the political party’s full name;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the party’s short-form name, or its abbreviation, if any, that is to be shown in election documents;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the party’s logo, if any;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the party’s leader and a copy of the party’s resolution to appoint the leader, certified by the leader and another officer of the party;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the address of the party’s office where records are maintained and to which communications may be addressed;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the names and addresses of the party’s officers and their signed consent to act in that capacity;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the party’s auditor and their signed consent to act in that capacity;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the name and address of the party’s chief agent and their signed consent to act in that capacity;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the names and addresses of 250 electors and their declarations in the prescribed form that they are members of the party and support the party’s application for registration; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the leader’s declaration in the prescribed form that, having considered all of the factors — including those described in subsection 521.1(5) — relevant to determining the party’s purposes, one of the party’s fundamental purposes is to participate in public affairs by endorsing one or more of its members as candidates and supporting their election.

Subsection.Text: To confirm that the purpose referred to in paragraph (2)(j) is one of the party’s fundamental purposes, the Chief Electoral Officer may ask the party’s leader to provide any relevant information, including information about the factors described in subsection 521.1(5).

Section.Text: A leader who has made an application under subsection 385(1) may withdraw it at any time before registration by sending a signed request to that effect to the Chief Electoral Officer.
A political party whose leader has made an application under subsection 385(1) becomes eligible for registration if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: its name, short-form name, abbreviation or logo does not

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: so resemble the name, short-form name, abbreviation or logo of a registered party or an eligible party that it would, in the Chief Electoral Officer’s opinion, likely be confused with it, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: include the word “independent” or a word that so resembles “independent” that it would, in the Chief Electoral Officer’s opinion, likely be confused with it;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the party has at least three officers in addition to its leader and has appointed a chief agent and an auditor; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the Chief Electoral Officer is satisfied that the party has provided the information required under subsection 385(2) and that the information is accurate.

Section.Text: In the period of 30 days after the deregistration of a political party,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: no application for another political party to become a registered party shall be accepted — and no report under section 405 is effective — if the application or report would permit another political party to use a name, short-form name, abbreviation or logo that would, in the Chief Electoral Officer’s opinion, likely be confused with that of the deregistered party; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if a new application is made for the registration of the deregistered party under the name, short-form name, abbreviation or logo that it had at the time of its deregistration, the Chief Electoral Officer shall not refuse the application on the ground that it does not comply with subparagraph 387(a)(i).

Subsection.Text: The Chief Electoral Officer shall, as soon as feasible after the day on which the application is received, inform the leader of a political party who has applied for the party to become registered whether or not the party is eligible for registration under section 387. If the party is not eligible, the Chief Electoral Officer shall also indicate which of that section’s requirements have not been met.
A political party whose leader has been informed under subsection (1) that it is eligible loses its eligibility if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it contravenes any of section 391, subsection 395(1), sections 399 to 402, subsections 405(1), (3) and (4) and 406(1) and section 407;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: one of its officers is not eligible under subsection 395(2) and the party has not complied with subsections 395(3) and (4);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: its chief agent is not eligible under section 397 and the party has not complied with section 400; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: its auditor is not eligible under section 398 and the party has not complied with section 400.

Subsection.Text: An eligible party becomes a registered party if it has at least one candidate whose nomination has been confirmed for an election and its application to become registered was made at least 60 days before the issue of the writ or writs and has not been withdrawn.

An eligible party whose application was made after the 60 days referred to in subsection (1) becomes a registered party for the next general election — or any by-election that precedes it — if it satisfies the requirements of that subsection for that election.
The Chief Electoral Officer shall, as soon as feasible after the end of the 48-hour period following the close of nominations,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
